data.text: INDEX
Purpose

To provide a reference guide for the schedule of information that should be disseminated to a patient throughout her pregnancy, during labour and following the birth of her baby. It should be read in conjunction with the clinical guidelines referred to throughout the guideline.

To ensure that pregnant patients, their partners and their families are treated with kindness, respect and dignity. Their views, beliefs and values in relation to a patient's care and that of her baby should be sought and respected at all times, enabling them to feel supported throughout their pregnancy and prepared for the birth and subsequent care of their baby.

Patients should have the opportunity to make informed decisions about their care and treatment throughout pregnancy, birth and during the postnatal period in partnership with their healthcare professionals. If patients do not have the capacity to make decisions, healthcare professionals should follow the Department of Health guidelines – ‘Reference guide to consent for examination or treatment'.
Every opportunity should be taken to provide the patient and her partner or other relevant family members with the information and support they need.
To ensure information is provided in a form that is easy to understand and accessible to pregnant patients with additional needs, such as physical, sensory or learning
disabilities, and to pregnant patients who do not speak or read English. Where available   leaflets in the relevant language should be used.
(Refer to the ‘Interpreting and translation policy'. Register number 09127A)
Patients choices should be recognised as being integral to the decision-making process.   Patient's decisions should be respected, even when this is contrary to the views of the
healthcare professional.
Equality Impact Assessment
Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to Appendix C)
Provision of Information
(Refer to the ‘Patient Information Policy'; register number )

All staff groups have a responsibility to provide impartial evidence based information to patients and their families in order that they are able to make an informed choice regarding their care and treatment. Patients should also be given enough time between receiving information and making choices based on the information, to consider their options and seek further information and advice as they so wish.
Patients should be offered opportunities to attend antenatal classes including breastfeeding workshops and have written information about antenatal care.

Patients should be offered verbal and where appropriate written information; and support to enable them to make informed decisions regarding their care. Information should include details of who will be their lead professional – midwife or obstetric consultant, and where and how their care will be provided.
Information provided should be easy to understand to meet the needs of the patients and   their partners.
Patients should be informed of their named professional during the antenatal, intrapartum and postnatal periods and when and why this has changed.
At each antenatal appointment, midwives and doctors should offer consistent information  and clear explanations and should provide pregnant patient with an opportunity to
discuss issues and ask questions in accordance with local guidelines and evidence-
based practice. If a referral to another professional is required this should be
documented in the designated place in the antenatal notes.

The midwife or GP completing the MAT AD 1 referral form should indicate the need for an interpreter and the language required. (Refer to the ‘Interpreting and Translation Policy'. Register number 09127A)

The midwife should arrange an interpreter prior to the booking appointment. The place of the booking may have to reflect the interpreting service availability and this should be continual throughout the antenatal, intrapartum and postnatal periods. (Refer to the ‘Interpreting and Translation Policy'. Register number 09127A)

Interpreting services must be used at booking and other appointments where important clinical information is given. (Refer to the guideline for ‘Interpreting and Translation Policy'. Register number 09127A)

Arrangement for screening test leaflets to be available in the appropriate language. Taking into account that patients who speak another language may not read in this language i.e. Bengali-speaking patient may not read Bengali. (Refer to the ‘Interpreting and Translation Policy'. Register number 09127A)

Patients' decisions should be respected, even when this is contrary to the views of the Health care professional and evidence for information provided and discussion must be clearly documented in patient's handheld records.
Antenatal Information
(Refer to the Guideline for Maternity Care. Register number 04272)
(Refer to Appendix A)
At the first point of contact patients should be offered information about pregnancy care services and options available, lifestyle considerations, including dietary information.
Patients should be given their handheld antenatal health care records to carry
throughout their pregnancy up to admission in labour. These records provide information   on:
Clinic appointments with dates, times and locations;
Hospital contact numbers;
Contact numbers for their named midwife;
Risk status;
Antenatal infant feeding checklist – to be discussed by  weeks gestation.
At booking, the midwife should discuss the antenatal screening program within Mid Essex supported by written information i.e. Public Health England's “Screening Tests for you
and your baby'.
(Refer to ‘Receiving and acting on test results in maternity by both Hospital and Community'; register number 06031)

“Screening tests for you and your baby” contains information on antenatal screening for haemoglobinopathies, screening for infectious diseases in pregnancy, ultrasound screening and Down's, Edward's and Patau's Syndrome screening.It is available in different languages at www.gov.uk/government/publications/screening-tests-for-you-and- your-baby-description-in-brief
In addition, the following information should be given and documented in the patient's Antenatal Care Records to pregnant patients in accordance with NICE guidance:
Folic acid supplementation;

Nutrition and diet discussing which foods to include and which foods to avoid – leaflet to be given. To include vitamin D supplementation for pregnant women and details of the ‘Healthy Start' programme (www.healthystart.nhs.uk);
Lifestyle advice, including smoking cessation, and the implications of recreational drug use and alcohol consumption in pregnancy;
How the baby develops during pregnancy;
Exercise, including pelvic floor exercises;
Options for place of birth;
Breastfeeding;
Antenatal classes for primigravid patients;
Discussion of mental health issues.

All women should receive a booklet entitled ‘Pregnancy Guide' which sets out MEHT Maternity Services, appointment schedule, screening tests, ultrasound scans, choice of where to deliver, antenatal workshops, physiotherapy, care during pregnancy, infections to be aware of, induction of labour, postnatal care, infant feeding and general information.

For those patients who decline blood products this should be clearly documented in the health care records and the “Management of pregnant and postnatal patients refusing blood products'; register Number 07040 should be followed. In MEHT, patients will provide information to the health care professional on which products they will accept.

All patients should receive ‘Pain relief in labour'; ideally this information should be discussed and given at  weeks gestation but for out of area women this information can be given at booking. For late bookers or women who have not received this information the information can be discussed, given and documented on an individual basis. Additionally, the healthcare records contain information on epidural anaesthesia check.
Patients who have had a previous caesarean section (LSCS) should be offered an appointment for the midwife led birth after caesarean section (BACS) clinic at 16 to 18 weeks of gestation.

At this appointment, the midwife for VBAC should provide information on VBAC, to include a discussion on mode of birth and fetal monitoring in labour. The midwife should document this discussion in the healthcare records (refer to the guidelines “Vaginal Birth after Caesarean Section' (VBAC)”; register number 06030; and “Fetal heart rate monitoring in pregnancy and labour'; register number 04265)
By  weeks of gestation, the breastfeeding antenatal checklist should be completed within the healthcare records. The checklist provides information to be discussed and given to all patients.

Patients diagnosed as having breech presentation at or after 36 weeks gestation should be offered an external cephalic version (ECV). ECV should be discussed and patients should receive written information.
(Refer to ‘Management of External Cephalic Version' (ECV); register number 08096)

At 36 weeks gestation, patients should be given the New Baby Guide booklet: this booklet provides the patient with information regarding the physical and psychological wellbeing for themselves and their baby. In addition, it provides information on local and national support groups.
Before or at  weeks patients should be provided with information on the following:

Breastfeeding information, including technique and good management practices that would help a mother succeed (the antenatal feeding checklist in the hand held records should be completed for all patients);
Off to the Best Start leaflet;
Preparation for labour and birth, including information about coping with pain in labour and the birth plan;
Recognition of active labour and the appropriate telephone number to ring/hospital to attend/midwife to contact (for homebirth);
Care of the new baby;
Vitamin K prophylaxis;
Newborn screening tests;
Postnatal self-care;
Awareness of ‘baby blues' and postnatal depression (PND).

The New Baby Guide also provides information on Vitamin K administration care. This guide should be ideally given at 36 weeks gestation but for out of area women this information can be given at booking. For late bookers or women who have not received this information the information can be discussed, given and documented on an individual basis.

When a decision has been agreed between the health care professional and the patient for an induction of labour, this should be discussed and the induction of labour leaflet given to the patient. The leaflet contains information on the process and procedures of induction.
(Refer to the “Induction of Labour (IOL) with prostaglandin, Propess, artificial rupture of membranes and Stretch and Sweep; register number 04291)

When a decision has been agreed between the health care professional and the patient for an elective LSCS as the safest mode of delivery, the midwife should ensure that the following patient information leaflets are given to the patient and that the following is
documented in the maternity record:
Admission procedure for caesarean section;
Caesarean section leaflet;
Obstetric Anaesthetists' Association booklet on Caesarean Sections;
Patients also receive a Mid Essex NHS leaflet ‘MRSA questions and answers for patients (Infection Prevention Team 2009) and the MRSA decontamination instruction sheet.

When a patient is referred to the anaesthetist for assessment during her pregnancy, the appropriate method of pain management should be discussed and documented in the patient's healthcare records by the anaesthetist.
Patients having a Glucose Tolerance Test (GTT) should be given an instruction leaflet and the FSC 2000 'the parents guide to money' for information about work, benefits and entitlements.
(Refer to Diabetes in pregnancy'; register number 04266)
Intrapartum Period
(Refer to ‘Management of normal labour and prolonged labour in low risk patients';
register number 09076 and ‘Fetal heart rate monitoring in pregnancy and labour'; register number 04265)
(Refer to Appendix A)
The name and grade of the professional responsible for the care of a patient must be clearly documented in the patient's healthcare records.
On admission in labour, the patient's risk status should be documented and the
method of fetal heart rate monitoring advised i.e. intermittent or continual. This should be discussed with the patient on admission.
If there is a requirement to transfer from intermittent to continual monitoring during labour, this should be discussed with the patient and documented in the health care records.
Pain management for labour should be discussed on review of the patients birth plan if appropriate, or during progress of labour. Discussions should be documented in the health care records.
If an epidural is requested by the patient or recommended by the healthcare
professional, the patient should have an anaesthetic assessment. Following assessment
discussions should be documented in the health care records and the epidural consent form within the healthcare records completed.
(Refer to “Vaginal Birth after Caesarean Section (VBAC)”. Register number 06030)

If an operative delivery is required, an anaesthetic assessment should be undertaken. Regional anaesthesia should be discussed between the patient and the anaesthetist. If a general anaesthetic is the preferred anaesthetic from an obstetric/anaesthetic opinion or requested by the patient, this should be documented in the healthcare records.
(Refer to “Vaginal Birth after Caesarean Section (VBAC)”; register number 06030)
Postnatal Period

Following delivery and the examination of the perineum, if repair is required, the need to suture should be discussed with the patient, an explanation provided of what the professional plans to do and why, and verbal consent given by the patient.
(Refer to “Assessment and repair of perineal trauma'; register number 07066; and to the “Routine postnatal care of women and their babies'; register number 09127)
(Refer to Appendix A)
If the repair needs to be performed in the obstetric theatre, point 5.6 should be followed.
Administration of Vitamin K should be discussed and parental consent gained.
(Refer to ‘Administration of vitamin K for neonates'; register number 08095)

During the postnatal period mothers should be given clear advice and information on aspects of care such as breast care, breastfeeding, care of the newborn, care of the perineum as appropriate, diet, hygiene, and discharge advice including contact details for health care professionals providing subsequent care.

Additional information specific to a mother's requirements i.e. 3rd/4th degree tears should be discussed and leaflet given as appropriate. (Refer to “Assessment and repair of perineal trauma'; register number 07066)

The discharge checklist in the Postnatal Care Record – Maternal should be completed on discharge from the hospital environment. This ensures that all information specific to a mother is discussed and the appropriate information leaflets given.

‘Public Health England's “Screening tests for you and your baby' provides information on the newborn screening neonatal blood spot. This should be discussed and parental consent gained prior to the testing. See sections 4.3 and 4.4. The health care professional should document consent gained in the health care records.
Continuity of arrangements should be maintained for those with a communication or language support need.
(Refer to ‘Interpreting and Translation Policy'; register number 09127A)
Documentation

All information given and discussed, as clinically indicated with patients during the antenatal, intrapartum and postnatal periods should be documented in the patient's healthcare records by the healthcare professional responsible. Patient information discussed and given during the antenatal period should be documented on the patient information proforma. (Refer to Appendix B)
Record keeping is integral to the role of all health care professionals caring for patients. “Keep clear and accurate records relevant to your practice” (NMC, 2015, point 10).

All staff must clearly document in the maternity records all discussions and provision of information to women, whether verbally, in leaflet form or included in maternity records, as clinically indicated in relation to the following:
Place of birth options (services provided locally);
Antenatal and postnatal screening tests – NSC leaflet available;
Induction of labour;
Fetal monitoring in labour (intermittent and electronic);
Pain management in labour (including anaesthesia and regional analgesia);
General Anaesthesia;
Vaginal birth following caesarean section – leaflet available;
Caesarean section;
Perineal repair – leaflet on 3rd & 4th degree tear available;
External cephalic version (ECV) – leaflet available (leaflet on breech);
Vitamin K prophylaxis (for baby) – leaflet available;
Patients who decline blood and blood products.

Where there is a current and relevant information leaflet (in English and other languages) this  should  be  given  to  the  woman  after  appropriate  discussion  l.  This  should  be documented in the maternity records. Patient information leaflets in other languages can be obtained through the ‘Big Word' interpreting services.
(Refer to ‘Interpreting and Translation Policy'; register number 09127A)
Staffing and Training
All midwifery and obstetric staff must attend yearly mandatory training which includes antenatal screening.
All midwifery and obstetric staff are to ensure that their knowledge and skills are up-to-date in order to complete their portfolio for appraisal.
Professional Midwifery Advocates

Professional Midwifery Advocates provide a mechanism of support and guidance to women and midwives. Professional Midwifery Advocates are experienced practising midwives who have undertaken further education in order to supervise midwifery services and to advise and support midwives and women in their care choices.
Audit and Monitoring

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy and the Maternity annual audit work plan. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group will identify a lead for the audit.
As a minimum the following specific requirements will be monitored:
Responsibilities of relevant staff groups;
Schedule of when the information should be given;
Process for providing information to women who have communication or language support needs;
Maternity service's expectations of staff to document clearly in the health records the information given to women as clinically indicated, in relation to:
Process for audit, multidisciplinary review of results and subsequent monitoring of action plans.

A review of a suitable sample of health records of patients to include the minimum requirements as highlighted in point  will be audited. A minimum compliance 75% is required for each requirement. Where concerns are identified more frequent audit will be undertaken.

The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.

The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group report will be reported to the Directorate Governance Meeting on a quarterly basis and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Patient Quality and Safety Committee (PSQC) within the Chief Nurse report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Guideline Management

As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.

Quarterly memos are sent to line managers to disseminate to their staff the most currently approved guidelines available via the intranet and clinical guideline folders, located in each designated clinical area.

Guideline monitors have been nominated in each clinical area to ensure a system whereby obsolete guidelines are archived and newly approved guidelines are downloaded from the intranet and filed appropriately in the guideline folders. ‘Spot checks' are performed on all clinical guidelines quarterly.
Quarterly Clinical Practices group meetings are held to discuss ‘guidelines'. During this meeting the practice development midwife can highlight any areas for future training
and needs can be met using methods such as ‘workshops' or be included in future ‘skills and drills' mandatory training sessions.
Communication

A quarterly ‘maternity newsletter' is issued to all staff to highlight key changes in clinical practice to include a list of newly approved guidelines for staff to acknowledge and familiarise themselves with and practice accordingly. Midwives on maternity leave or ‘bank' staff will have letters sent to their home address to update them on current clinical changes.
Approved guidelines are published monthly in the Trust's Staff Focus that is sent via email to all staff.
Approved guidelines will be disseminated to appropriate staff quarterly via email.

Regular memos are posted on the guideline and audit notice boards in each clinical area to notify staff of the latest revised guidelines and how to access guidelines via the intranet or clinical guideline folders.
References

National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health. (2008). Antenatal care: routine care for the healthy pregnant woman. 2008 Update. London: The Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists Press.
NMC (2015) The Code: Professional standards of practice and behavior for nurses, midwives and nursing associates. London: NMC
Knight, M et al (2017) Saving lives, improving mothers care. Oxford: MBRRACE-UK Mental Capacity Act 2005. (c.9) London: HMSO
Department of Health. (2004) National Service Framework for children, young people and maternity services: maternity services. London: Department of Health
RCOG (2004) Caesarean Section guidelines. National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health Commissioned by the National Institute for Clinical Excellence
NICE(2011) Caesarean Section. Clinical Guideline (CG132). London: NICE
NICE (2008) Antenatal care for uncomplicated pregnancies. Clinical Guideline (CG62). London: NICE
The Baby Friendly Initiative (website) http://www.unicef.org.uk/babyfriendly/
Appendix A
Timing and Responsibility for Discussion and Provision of Information
